The recently launchedNorwich Union Direct offers a motorcycle policy and existingpolicyholders may see advantages in buying direct in the future.Premiums fell again last year, reflecting increasing competition aswell as a significant fall in biking accidents.  In 1994, thesetotalled 25,100, a reduction of more than half the figure of 65,300recorded for 1984.  As the number of motorcycles also halved over thesame period, the statistics are not as encouraging as they mightappear.  However, there are signs that insurers are beginning to revisetheir view of motorcyclists as high risks, particularly as a new breedof more mature "enthusiast" motorcyclists is emerging.  The currentpremium value of the market is estimated at #150m.In the wake of Norwich Union's introduction of group-rated cover in1994, Lombard General followed suit last year, with rates designed for20 different categories.Uninsured loss recoveryThe ULR policies described are for legal expenses associated withprivate motor and marine risks.  They all have to be purchased and inforce before the insured event takes place apart from Motorists LegalProtection's After the Accident policy.  This is a stand-alone policydesigned for purchase by an accident victim - motorist, cyclist orpedestrian - following an accident to cover the future legal costs ofpursuing a claim arising from that accident.Motor ULR insurance is now widely sold in the UK, with most motorinsurers offering their policyholders the chance to add on legalexpenses cover.  Both DAS Legal Expenses Insurance and CornhillInsurance have recently produced upgraded versions of their standardproducts, while DAS also offers a more basic policy.Introduction of the conditional fee system in the UK last year,accompanied by the launch of a conditional fee insurance scheme backedby the Law Society,  led to some confusion among brokers as to thecontinued need for ULR cover.    For #85 premium, the Law Society'sscheme - Accident Line Protect - pays up to #100,000 of costs awardedagainst plaintiffs if they lose a personal injury case.  It is arrangedby Johnson & Higgins in association with the insurers' agents AbbeyLegal Protection, and placed with Lexington Insurance, part of AIG.Motoring Uninsured Loss Recoveries Association (MULRA) chairman PaulAsplin has responded with assurances that conditional fees will notmake any impact on the desirability or need for ULR cover.  Over 80% ofnon-fault motor accidents do not involve personal injury and in suchcases the conditional fee system is not available.  He also pointed outthat, under the conditional fee system, plaintiffs are left to pick upthe costs awarded against them if they fail their case.  He statedthat, with the new conditional fee insurance scheme, plaintiffs mightfind that the full amount of damages recovered was swallowed upon incosts before the insurance cover came into play.Back to Headline List CopyrightPERSONAL POLICY GUIDE via NewsNetJanuary 1, 1996NEW SUBSIDENCE RATING SYSTEMHiscox Underwriting is pioneering a revolutionary system, provided bythe British Geological Survey (BGS), for rating the subsidence risk ofindividual properties.  The computerised system - known as the GeoHazard Susceptibility Package 2 (GHASP 2) - is based on the BGS's1:10,000-scale geological maps, the most detailed information on geohazards available across the UK.  It enables the underwriter topinpoint the precise bedrock beneath individual properties, even wheresituated close to other properties.Hiscox says that the system represents a major advance on other currentmethods of assessing subsidence risk, which are based just on the firstthree or four digits of a postcode and give only the average risk forgroups of several hundred homes.  It claims that use of GHASP 2 willlead to premium savings of up to 60% for existing policyholders withlower risk properties that are currently included within higher riskpostcodes, and even bigger reduction for policyholders moving to theunderwriter from other insurers.The new rating system is being applied to the underwriter's 606 HighValue House and Contents Policy and will be used in particular to rateproperties in southern England, where many postcodes are susceptiblelocally to a wide variety of geo hazards.Back to Headline List CopyrightPERSONAL POLICY GUIDE via NewsNetJanuary 1, 1996RIAS DISCOUNTSThe Retirement Insurance Advisory Service (RIAS) is giving discounts ofup to 15% to customers taking out a joint contents and buildings policyas part of the RIAS Home Insurance Plan.  David Holden, RIAS generalsecretary, said that its research showed that customers who choose tocover their home contents and structure together under one policy are abetter risk than those who take out separate contents or buildingscover.  RIAS home insurance policyholders can also add a special HomeHelp Benefit to their existing cover for only #1 per month.  Thisprovides up to #50 per week for eight weeks should the policyholderaccidentally break or fracture a bone.Back to Headline List CopyrightPERSONAL POLICY GUIDE via NewsNetJanuary 1, 1996EDI AVAILABILITYAll Norman Insurance private car products are now available via EDI toany Continuum Ra brokers with a Norman agency.  .Initially, thisaffects new business only but facilities for mid term adjustments willfollow later in 1996.Back to Headline List CopyrightPERSONAL POLICY GUIDE via NewsNetJanuary 1, 1996RATES WARNINGSpecialist motor insurer Insurance (GB) warns that changes inreinsurance rates and the need for bigger reserves will inevitably putpressure on rates.  Recent legal developments have introduced the useof actuarial evidence in determining multipliers and the adoption of adiscount rate linked to the yield of index linked governmentsecurities.  These combined factors will have an enormous impact uponthe claims burden falling to UK motor insurers and reinsurers, says theinsurer.Relevant developments are the production of the "Ogden" tables and theCivil Evidence bill in October 1995 which permits courts to adopt Ogdenmultipliers in the assessment of personal injury damages in all futurecases brought before them.  This means that if a personal injury claimfor an accident that occurred in, say, 1988 now comes before the court,Ogden multipliers may be applied to the assessment of that claim.It has been estimated that these new multipliers will produce a generalincrease in claims of between 15% and 25% but could be as high as 50%.Not all claims will be affected but plaintiff solicitors are currentlypleading Ogden level multipliers in approximately 10% of all cases.This percentage is sure to rise very quickly, warns Insurance (GB), asotherwise there could be implications for solicitors' E&O policies.The insurer states that the overall effect will be an increase ininsurers' reserves for outstanding claims, which will be seen in manyreinsurance programmes now under negotiation as well as those in thefuture.  As the introduction is retrospective, the 1996 revenue yearwill see adverse developments due to increased reserves on prior yearclaims.Significant effects are already being shown on quotations forreinsurance for 1996.  Insurance (GB) concludes that these increases,coupled with the deterioration in claims reserves, will almostcertainly force appreciable premium increases on the industry earlythis year.Back to Headline List CopyrightPERSONAL POLICY GUIDE via NewsNetJanuary 1, 1996WORST EUROPEAN RECORD FOR CAR CRIMEBritish motorists are at much greater risk of having their cars stolenthan drivers in the rest of Europe, according to the second annualEuropean Car Crime study by Eagle Star.  The study, compiled from thelatest EU government and insurance organisation statistics, comparedthe number of cars stolen in 1994 in each country with the total numberof cars in use.The UK has by far the worst record for car crime, with an average of 22cars per thousand on the road stolen in 1994.  That is nearly doublethe level in the next worst country, France, where 12.5 cars perthousand were stolen in 1994.  The study found that car theft is lowestin Austria where less than two cars per thousand were stolen in 1994.The next most secure country was Switzerland, where just three perthousand cars went missing.Overall, a lower proportion of cars were stolen in 1994 than in 1993.The European average fell from 11.7 thefts per thousand cars to 9.7.In the UK, the proportion was down from 29 to 22 per thousand.Back to Headline List CopyrightPERSONAL POLICY GUIDE via NewsNetJanuary 1, 1996COMBATING CAR "RINGERS"A Code of Practice for the Disposal of Motor Vehicle Salvage has beenproduced by the Association of British Insurers and Lloyd's MotorUnderwriters' Association to help eliminate the practice of "ringing",whereby the identity of a written-off vehicle is transferred to astolen vehicle by criminals.  The Code sets out the steps to be takenby insurers and salvage dealers in the disposal of vehicles whichcannot be economically or safely repaired.All total loss vehicles are placed into one of four categories,depending on the extent of the damage, with the necessary action to betaken in each case.  Vehicles in Category A are suitable for scraponly; Category B should be broken for spare parts.  DVLA is notifiedand the police are asked to investigate if the vehicle is relicensed oran application for a registration document made.  Categories C and Dcover vehicles which can be repaired.Back to Headline List CopyrightPERSONAL POLICY GUIDE via NewsNetJanuary 1, 1996COMPUTER TRACINGAbsolute Software Corporation, Canada, has introduced CompuTrace TRS,which it claims is the world's first computer tracing technology andtheft retrieval system.  Absolute Software monitors the location of itscustomer's computers using CompuTrace, a software program which isundetectable once it is loaded onto the hard drive of the computer.The program takes control of the computer's modem once a week, turnsthe modem's speakers off and then secretly dials Absolute Software'stoll-free monitoring centre where the call is logged.If a computer is lost or stolen, the customer contacts the CompuTraceTheft Retrieval Centre to report the incident.  Once the theft isreported, the customer's account is changed to alert status, so thatthe call will be traced.  If a thief connects the stolen computer'smodem to a telephone line, when CompuTrace makes its scheduled call,the Theft Retrieval Centre tracks the call using advanced equipmentthat cannot be interfered with by call-blocking methods.CompuTrace does not disrupt work while it makes a call.  If the modemis in use or disconnected, the system waits until a telephone line isopen or connected.  It does not show up in the file directory, and willsurvive even if the hard disk is formatted.  CompuTrace works with anyDOS or Windows 3.1 based computer as long as it is equipped with amodem.  Absolute Software will release Windows 95, Macintosh and OS/2versions of CompuTrace this spring.Back to Headline List CopyrightPERSONAL POLICY GUIDE via NewsNetJanuary 1, 1996CORNHILL PEGS PREMIUMSCornhill Insurance is pegging premiums paid by its TravelCoverpolicyholders at 1994 rates (excluding Insurance Premium Tax).Improved benefits include* a three day premium rate for both UK (adults #6.00 and child #3.00)and European travel (adult #9.00 and child #4.50)* improved family premium rates with one child covered free in a partyof two adults and two children* a five per cent premium discount for groups of 10 travellers.Back to Headline List CopyrightPERSONAL POLICY GUIDE via NewsNetJanuary 1, 1996ESCALATING MEDICAL COSTS, SKI RESORTSThe cost of having an injury treated in the world's most popular skidestinations continues to climb rapidly, according to the second annualstudy of medical costs by Home & Overseas, specialist travel subsidiaryof Eagle Star.  The study, based on an analysis of claims for medicalexpenses submitted by skiers, shows that Britons can expect to pay atleast 10% more than last winter for treatment in their resort - thesecond year running that costs have risen at this level.Topping the table of the most expensive places for medical treatmentare resorts in Switzerland and the USA.  For example, the cost oftreating a damaged knee cartilage, requiring three days in-patientcare, now averages around #4,000 in Switzerland and #6,000 in the US.Helicopter rescues now cost around #60 for every minute the helicopteris in the air. REGULATORY LOBBYING (128 words) DOI'S FRAZIER TO HEAD INITIATIVE (126 words) QUOTE OF THE ISSUE (31 words) CopyrightWORKERS' COMP EXECUTIVE via NewsNetJanuary 8, 1996CARRIERS PLAN TO FOCUS ON MAKING REGS MORE EFFECTIVE (PART 1)SACRAMENTO - The assembly is in the hands of conservative Republican CurtPringle of Garden Grove. The state senate is controlled by a liberal Democrat,Bill Lockyer of Hayward. There is a very significant election - from alegislative standpoint -coming up this fall. And so the California workers'comp insurance lobby is taking a reality check on the chances of any importantbills being passed this year.The general thinking is that any significant improvements in the system have abetter chance of coming from new or improved regulations that implemented orshould have implemented reforms passed in 1989, 1990 and 1993.One lobbyist told the Executive,"I don't think public policymakers feel theneed to do any major workers' comp reform. So efforts at improving theworkers' comp system should be viewed as: What can we do? What can enough ofthe stakeholders agree to so that they can put something on Wilson's desk?"Other lobbyists agreed that major reforms are unlikely, but that some cleanupbills from last year are a possibility. Assemblyman David Knowles,R-Placerville, has informed the lobby that he is interested in the permanentpartial disability issue and looking at ways to legislatively enact theAmerican Medical Association guidelines as the impairment rating system.The Commission on Health and Safety and Workers' Compensation reportedly isconsidering a study on the schedule to determine whether or not it has a majorimpact on the cost of workers' comp and whether or not it adequatelycompensates the injured worker, says Barry Carmody, president of theAssociation of California Insurance Companies.According to Mark Webb, senior counsel for the Coalition of CaliforniaCompensation Companies, the assembly-man's exposure PPD draft, that is makingthe rounds, would also make some significant revisions to the med-legalprocess. While the measure is gaining support by the day, Webb feels it isalso the type of bill that would likely face difficulty getting passed thisyear.At the top of the list of 1996 legislative goals for the Alliance of AmericanInsurers happens to be an effort to pass two of their bills from 1995 - AB1046 and AB 1859."What they have in common," says Pete Gorman, assistant vice president of theAlliance, "is that they reduce the discretionary authority of the Departmentof Industrial Relations. One (AB 1046) brings them in under the OAL (Office ofAdministrative Law). The other prohibits them from assigning out the lienservice process."A second top priority item for the Alliance is one that is on everyone's hitlist, effective action on the Tricor v. State Fund case."I don't think the bureau's (WCIRB) weighting scheme (frequency basedexperience modifications) does it," says Gorman. "It just flies in the face ofevery traditional way of developing X-Mods."Gorman is also leery of a proposal to give the insurance commissioneradministrative authority to review disputes before they went to litigation."We don't agree with that approach," he says. "I think it's too bureaucratic.And the cost-benefit probably isn't there. What we may do...It seems to me tobe much easier just to run a bill that declares legislative intent thatelevates the standard for litigation from one of injury to one of bad faith."He explains that an aggrieved employer would have to demonstrate that aworkers' comp carrier had taken a certain action in bad faith in order to haveit actionable. As it is now, he says, the employer can say unintentional orintentional, "we suffered an injury and so therefore we can sue."Gorman says, "So just raise the bar on where you can sue. That would be a muchbetter way to do this, because I don't think the legislature ever intendedthis consequence of Tricor. They wanted only to give employers access to thefiles." A third Alliance legislative goal is an updated medical fee schedule."We've already filed a letter saying we think it's going to end up being afloor instead of a ceiling," Gorman fears. "And for small companies, we'replaced at a disadvantage. We don't have the leverage and the bargaining powerto get it down below that floor, whereas the big companies do."The American Insurance Association has a list of specific issues on which itwould like to see action taken during 1996. Terry Miller, assistant vicepresident, expresses concern over one of the first issues that needs to bedealt with, the hospital fee schedule proposed by the Division of Workers'Compensation."The AIA says we should postpone it," Miller relates. "We believe there iscurrently insufficient information to accurately gauge the impact of theschedule on workers' comp hospital costs."Miller also notes that there appears to be no hospital fee schedule anywherein the US that is widely supported as THE model.The AIA is also involved with PPD and the benefits of permanent partialdisability. It is working on a PPD bill but that the effort is in a veryembryonic stage at this point. Miller said that there were several bills onthe subject being floated around for comment.A third key issue for the AIA is fraud. Miller says that the AIA has beendiscussing the subject with the Department of Insurance "because it wants somefraud legislation." Exactly what it should be, how broad it should be andwhether it should be geared just to workers' comp is still not determined.Given the possibility of legislative gridlock, Webb of the CCCC sees theprincipal focus for the year should be on reviewing all that's been put inplace over the last five years and seeing "what we can do with Casey Young,Chip Aubrey and Chuck Quackenbush to make at least the best world we can withwhat we have to deal with."It's no surprise that Tricor is on CCCC's list, and Webb says, "We will workclosely with the California Workers' Compensation Institute and see what typesof things can be done to, at least, bring it into sharper focus - what thecourts need to look at in dealing with these types of bad faith lawsuits.."Back to Headline List CopyrightWORKERS' COMP EXECUTIVE via NewsNetJanuary 8, 1996CARRIERS PLAN TO FOCUS ON MAKING REGS MORE EFFECTIVE (PART 2)Webb said that he felt it was significant that the CWCI board in Decemberdecided to "take a step back" on any actions toward Tricor. The question theyhad in mind was whether or not there would be any more such suits once thesystem had completely shifted to competitive rating. The practices that hadcome under fire in Tricor were a phenomenon of the minimum rate law era soonto be in the dim and distant past.Webb adds, "At the same time, let's look at ways that insurance cases can bebetter made in the courts so that potentially we don't have 12 jurors suddenlybecoming claims managers."The CCCC plans to present testimony on the permanent disability schedule tothe Commission on Health and Safety and Workers' Compensation at its hearingon January 18 in Los Angeles. The hearing should be a packed house.Webb says the association will then look at vehicles currently in place,including Senator Steve Peace's SB 622 which was designed last year to makethe Chula Vista Democrat's 1993 health care organization law more effective.The CCCC has been working with the California Association of HMOs to invent anoncontroversial means for implementing managed care in a more effective way.Webb notes that it's a task that's easier said than done."If we have some good treatment guidelines promulgated by the IndustrialMedical Council (and we're able) to combine those with...good utilization dataguidelines already in place, we may be able to get somewhere," Webb reasons."And that goes back to saying we need to get 1989, 90 and 93 implementedbefore we can come back (to the legislature) and say this doesn't work."In order to make the HCO process work, there will have to be changes in thestructural flaws - "multiple offerings, the multiple time frame, the abilityto opt out," Webb observes. They make it difficult for a capitated arrangementto work. "All those are reasons why it has not received much of a response inthe marketplace."But the point Webb wanted to stress was that there were other medical costcontainment devices that were put in place in 1993, "that aren't there, thataren't being done right now." Webb says, "That goes back to the IMC andtreatment guidelines which could make managed care work even better under just30-day control. And we're seeing a lot of managed care marketing using that30-day control."The ACIC's Carmody wants to champion a review of regulations. "There are justtoo many regulations," says Carmody, "that cost too much money and that don'tprovide any additional services to workers, attorneys, insurers or anybodyelse." The way to get the ball rolling, he suggests is to get all of thestakeholders to ask the questions: "Why am I getting this report? Why am Iproducing this report? Why do I have to have this report?"He said you need to take the reporting alone, forgetting the conduct ofbusiness, and evaluate what is really critical and essential, and what is not.Then you make recommendations to the administration "saying we think theseregulations, these records, this material required by regulation isunnecessary, and it's a cost-driver. And let the administration make adecision on whether it wants to repeal the regs or not."Carmody observes that it doesn't mean the regulations are going to be changedautomatically but it does mean that those being regulated will have theopportunity to provide their perspective on the value of the regulations."The governor basically called for this," Carmody notes. "He called for allagencies to review their regs. The problem is the agencies do it alone. Theydo it in a vacuum, a bureaucratic one in which they decide what is right andwrong, or what is good and bad for the regulated public."Carmody emphatically adds, "Frankly, they're not elected. And the public oughtto have some input on whether or not these regulations are needed."The ACIC president feels there are kindred souls out there who aren't fond ofall the reports they have to fill out and submit to bureaucrats."I remember after the '89 and '93 reforms, the moaning from all of theattorneys about all the paper one has to go through. And all of the reportsthat are thrown in the trash can because their workers don't understand them,"Carmody said. "Perhaps the benefit notices report process is the mostludicrous of them all. They started out at about 15 and are up to 150 now.Why? Why!"Back to Headline List CopyrightWORKERS' COMP EXECUTIVE via NewsNetJanuary 8, 1996AIA, CCCC CONFIRM W/C EXEMPTION FROM 1995'S EXPERT WIITNESS LAWSACRAMENTO - An opinion by the California Legislative Counsel has put smileson the faces of more than just a few members of the workers' comp insurancecommunity in California.The Counsel has determined that legislation passed last year does not subjectemployers and insurers to additional expert witness fees in cases before theWorkers' Compensation Appeals Board. The legislation, AB 1204, was stronglyopposed by several company trade associations which requested the governor toveto. He didn't.Once the measure was chaptered, representatives from the American InsuranceAssociation and the Coalition of California Compensation Companies jointlyrequested that Assemblyman David Knowles (R-Placerville), chairman of theAssembly Insurance Committee, seek a Counsel clarification on whether the lawresulting from passage of AB 1204 applied to workers' comp."This opinion puts to rest any question about the testimony of medicalwitnesses in workers' compensation cases," said Terry Miller, AIA assistantvice president, western region. "It is clear that the director of the Divisionof Workers' Compensation has the authority for setting witness fees byestablishing a medical-legal fee schedule."The Legislative Counsel's opinion specifically states: "The fees for witnessesproviding medical testimony before the Workers' Compensation Appeals Board orin other workers' compensation proceedings are not affected by the amendmentsto Section 1034 of the Code of Civil Procedure enacted by Chapter 797 of theStatutes of 1995 (AB 1204)."Miller explained, "The expert witness fee is exactly the kind of hidden costthat we sought to eliminate with the 1993 reforms. The insurance industry mustcontinue working together to ensure that those reforms are fully implemented.Cooperative efforts, such as confirming the witness fee workers' compexemption, will ensure that cost savings for employers are realized."The AIA and the CCCC have asked Casey Young, administrative director of theDivision of Workers' Compensation, to review current Workers' CompensationAppeals Board rules regarding witness fees to make certain that they areconsistent with the provisions of Section 5307.6 of the Labor Code, whichauthorizes the director to establish the medical-legal fee schedule.Back to Headline List CopyrightWORKERS' COMP EXECUTIVE via NewsNetJanuary 8, 1996CA-BASED W/C CARRIERS RANKED BY DIRECT LOSS RATIO, 1994 3RD QUARTERSAN FRANCISCO - The third quarter 1995 workers' comp insurance figures forCalifornia-based carriers, a regular feature in the Executive, are reported onpage 3.The carriers are ranked according to their direct loss ratios with the highestat the top of the page, lowest at the bottom. The totalcommitment of capacity is #225m, added to which is a further #18m fromsingle corporate member syndicate 1211 backed by USF&G Corp, BaltimoreMD.Mid Ocean and Brockbank will create a group which brings together theexisting Brockbank managing agency businesses with Baltusrol, a US$78mMid Ocean subsidiary created as the holding company for two new Lloyd'sdedicated corporate syndicates underwriting in parallel withBrockbank's existing syndicates.  Mid Ocean will have a 51% share ofthe enlarged Brockbank Group, and $50m of Baltusrol's capital willprovide capacity for the two corporate syndicates.  Brockbank'sbusiness will substantially be transferred into a new unit, BrockbankHoldings, which will exchange shares with Baltusrol, the latter taking51% in Brockbank Holdings and Brockbank Holdings 49% in Baltusrol.  Ashareholders' agreement between the two groups includes undisclosedundertakings providing Brockbank with equally undisclosed "additionalrights" for a limited period, while Mid Ocean received a commitmentthat the transaction may be unwound if certain "trigger events", mainlyrelated to the acceptance of the Lloyd's rescue plan and the futurestability of the market, occur or do not occur before 1 September.Otherwise, Mid Ocean will acquire all but one share of Brockbank by 1September 1997 at a price independently determined, in cash or MidOcean shares, or loan notes.  Brockbank executives representing 28.6%of issued shares have already committed themselves to accept the offer. However, the company's lifebusiness itself will be moved away from that company into a new,Hamburg-based life insurer, leaving HDI Leben as an empty shell with aconsiderable tax-loss to carry forward.  HDI Leben will be renamed andconverted into a sub-holding under the parent HDI VVaG, and into whichall operational insurance interests outside the actual HDI VVaG will bebundled, including those of reinsurer Hannover Ruckversicherung AG,Hanover, and its subsidiary Eisen und Stahl Ruckversicherung AG.Such a setup (parental mutuals, sub-holding for other interests) is theclassic model for a "Gleichordnungskonzern", a group formed of twomutuals which cannot formally merge.  The group is then held togetherby a joint management for both, and by stakes in the sub-holding, intowhich the mutuals bring their non-mutualised insurance business.  MrBaumgartl does not deny that this could be a model and although he saysthat there are "no current talks going on", it seems likely that such amove towards an alliance with a life mutual would not be unwelcome tohim.Following the signing of the deal with Citibank, Mr Baumgartl said that"In order to be a global player on the life market, you need premiumincome of about DM2bn" (US$1.4bn).  His present life companies are farshort of that: to 30 November, Citi Leben reported premium income ofDM322m for 1995, so the total for the year will be below DM400m.Transleben reported DM216m for 1994, and the 1995 total is likely to bebelow DM300m.  HDI's own life company is still struggling with theproblems of being relatively new, and premium income will total onlyDM36m. Together, therefore, the whole HDI life group will write notmore than DM650m - and it is difficult to see where HDI will gain theDM2bn it is seeking, if Mr Baumgartl does not have a major partnershipup his sleeve.The deal with Citibank was not surprising, and aimed as much at volumeas the sales channels offered by the two companies.  Citi Leben has atotal life portfolio of DM16.7bn and Citi Versicherung gross premium ofDM23.5m.  The former Citibank insurers will continue as companies intheir own right, and will change their names to CiV LebensversicherungAG and CiV Versicherung AG.  Product names like "Citi Leben Plus 4"will also remain unchanged, and policies will continue to be soldexclusively through the sales channels of Citibank Privatkunden.  Thosechannels - reaching at present about 2.5m customers - were of keyimportance for HDI, Mr Baumgartl stressed.  "That is why we were onlyinterested in an exclusive and long-term cooperation with Citibank.Without Citibank's salesforce, the two insurers would be of no valuefor us!" he said, adding that by co-operating with Citibank, HDI hadcompleted its range of distribution channels.  HDI had no interest inbecoming an Allfinanz group, Mr Baumgartl said.HDI will sell banking products exclusively for Citibank, and in returnCitibank will only offer CiV and other HDI policies in the insurancesector.  Mr Baumgartl said that there would be no assimilation betweenthe Citi and HDI products.  "The CiV products will remain tailor-madefor Citibank's demands," he saidAccording to Mr Baumgartl, HDI's moves to strengthen its life businesswere needed to counterbalance the sharp swings in the profits of theindustrial, motor and portfolios which were the group's major lines ofbusiness. The court said that the German insurance supervisionBundesaufsichtsamt fur das Versicherungswesen (BAV), Berlin, had actedcorrectly when it allowed the 1989 transfer of the life portfolio fromthe mutual R+V Lebensversicherungsverein aG to the joint stock companyR+V Lebensversicherung AG, Wiesbaden.Several insureds of the old mutual had taken legal action against BAV,complaining that the compensation paid to members was too low and didnot take the hidden reserves of the mutual adequately into account. The plaintiffs argued thatthe hidden reserves totalled "a multiple" of that sum.The court said that the BAV had taken sufficient care of the interestsof policyholders.  The legal and effective material situation of theplaintiffs had not been worsened to a noteworthy degree.  As far asthey had suffered losses at all, they had been compensated.  Thetransfer of the portfolio was no reason to dissolve the hiddenreserves.  The BAV's agreement to the deal did not prevent members fromsuing for higher compensation.The judgement is of considerable importance because it eases thetransformation from mutuals to joint stock companies.  Many mutualssuffer from inadequate equity, and must increase capital throughprofits.  The EU directive on the solvency of insurance groups which isin preparation would aggravate the problem for life mutuals, asreserves for premium repayments to policyholders would no longer countas equity.Back to Headline List WT03-B03-4IA086-000615-B045-11http://telnet.newsnet.com:80/libiss/in14.html 205.156.212.5 19970122021320 text/html 78756HTTP/1.0 200 OKServer: Netscape-Commerce/1.12Date: Wednesday, 22-Jan-97 02:11:14 GMTLast-modified: Monday, 20-Jan-97 17:39:30 GMTContent-length: 78569Content-type: text/html /data/webdev/libiss/in14.html Sample Issue Copyright WORLD INSURANCE REPORT via NewsNet January 12, 1996 SAMPLE ISSUE HEADLINES EURO THOUGHTS (765 words) PUBLICATIONS REVIEW SWISS RE ON SOLVENCY (938 words) ROI IMPROVED (673 words) STATE REINSURER, NEW COMPANIES (249 words) NEW LIFE INSURER FOR THOSE RESETTLED BY DAM PROJECT (141 words) NINE FOREIGN APPLICANTS (143 words) CCI ON MARKET REFORM (243 words) MINIMUM CAPITAL INCREASED (160 words) MOTOR POOL PROPOSED (177 words) MOTOR THEFT ESCALATING (213 words) EARTHQUAKE LIMIT RAISED (170 words) GLASS-STEAGALL AMENDMENTS CLOSE TO VOTE (185 words) PEOPLE'S BANKCORP GRANTED INSURANCE LICENCE (84 words) NEWS NEW LAW IMMINENT (47 words) AMENDED LAW IN FORCE (255 words) NEW SUPERVISION COMMISSION (179 words) MORE CATS, LOSSES LOWER (330 words) DISASTERS BILL UNDER FIRE (281 words) WINDSTORM MARKET ASSISTANCE PROPOSAL (87 words) STORM INSURANCE PREMIUMS TO RISE (141 words) TAX BREAK "CRITICAL" FOR EQ PLAN (252 words) "FAIR TORRENT" OF SNOW CLAIMS (345 words) BUILDING CODE PROPOSED (285 words) 1996 CAPACITY (95 words) IN THE COURTS (272 words) LLOYD'S INVESTMENT TRUSTS RULING (53 words) LLOYD'S TO SCRAP HARDSHIP SCHEME (59 words) LLOYD'S OF LONDON PRESS SOLD IN MANAGEMENT BUYOUT (38 words) VETO TO BE OVERTURNED? (138 words) CALIFORNIA PROPOSES NO-FAULT (151 words) PROPOSITION 103 RULING (48 words) NEW WORKERS' COMP SCHEME (340 words) LANDMARK MEDMAL RULING (421 words) OCCURRENCE AND REPORTS PROPERTY AND BUSINESS INTERRUPTION (786 words) MARINE (164 words) ROAD/RAIL (257 words) AVIATION (360 words) LIABILITY, AWARDS, SETTLEMENTS (132 words) NATURAL CATASTROPHES (898 words) CopyrightWORLD INSURANCE REPORT via NewsNetJanuary 12, 1996EURO THOUGHTSWITH THE DEADLINE of 1 January 1999 fixed by the Cannes Summit at theend of June 1995, European insurers have begun to consider theconsequences for them of a move to a single European currency.  Allstudies have reached the same conclusion: most of the costs generatedby the move to the single currency will occur during the preparatoryphase whereas the majority of benefits will only appear after theimplementation of the single currency, the Comite Europeen desAssurances (CEA) said in a preliminary commentary.  There is thereforea real economic interest in limiting the transitional period for themove from one system to the other, while allowing the necessary timefor adaptation, it said.Recurrent monetary crises in Europe over the last three years, havelargely shown that despite the EMS, Europe regularly suffers fromunbridled speculation aimed in particular at weaker currencies.  Thecreation of a single currency in Europe would in theory be one solutionto such attacks and the only one capable in limiting such destabilizingbehaviour.  That participating states should meet on a sustainablebasis the criteria of convergence born when they join and in future isa sine qua non for the success of the process but not insufficient initself, the CEA concluded.Although technical differences exist between life and non-lifeinsurance, globally the prospect of monetary stability in Europe isvery much in the interest of insurance, especially life insurance.  Thereinforcement of monetary stability should achieve a fall in long-terminterest rates and greater confidence by the public in the singlecurrency which should, eventually, gain status as a reserve currencylike the dollar.  An end to exchange rate manipulation, thedisappearance of exchange rate risks between member states and theoptimum allocation of financial resources permitted by a singlecurrency were particularly important for European insurers as they maynow invest assets anywhere in the European Economic Area, the CEA said. A more favourable business climate should result and European insurerswould also be able to propose contracts in a single currency to clientsoutside the EU.At a micro-economic level, a single currency will reduce the cost oftransactions and bank transfers to insurers and make for better pricecomparability and improve the quality of service offered.Supplementary costs would be incurred because of modification ofcomputer programmes and financial management systems, re-denominationof policies and other documents and some staff reorganisation.Although the CEA found it probable that these changes will eventuallybring about gains in productivity and competitiveness, "it isundeniable that they will represent, in the short term, a majoroutlay".  Most insurers, however, would consider these costs asinvestments, if the return on costs incurred was reasonably guaranteedby firm and irrevocable commitments by governments on the continuity ofthe process, it suggested.Among obstacles likely to cause difficulties are the absence of aprecise, detailed timetable or a firm political commitment to conformto it, which creates uncertainty, the CEA said.  Even if commitmentsare given in this respect, insurers fear that insufficient co-ordination of monetary policies, or sudden economic and/or socialdifficulties in one or more states would have disastrous effects on theprocess as a whole.The absence of harmonisation in taxation (as well as in state socialsecurity schemes) could also cause tension and constitute a barrier toexpected developments, the CEA considered.  The problem is the absenceof harmonisation of indirect taxation on savings and co-ordination offiscal provisions on overall assets and benefits.  The CEA raised anumber of issues with members with regard to the Green Paper onmonetary union published at the end of May by the European Commission.The majority of European insurers favours a big bang solution, viewingthe three-year preparation period envisaged in the Green Paper as toolong.  During the transitional period (phase B) a large critical massof business must be undertaken in the single currency.  Undertakingsshould not have to use double accounting during phase B even if theyunderwrite single currency contracts from the start of 1999, the CEAstressed.  Only national currencies will still be legal tender duringphase B, but as they will become real substitutes for the singlecurrency, conversion rates into the single currency, fixed irrevocably,must make it possible for an automatic and cost-free move from any onenational currency to the single currency and back.  A Europeandirective was also required to stipulate that the move to the singlecurrency may not in itself be used unilaterally to cancel currentcontracts.Back to Headline List CopyrightWORLD INSURANCE REPORT via NewsNetJanuary 12, 1996SWISS RE ON SOLVENCYFinancial security of insurers is increasingly important in theindustry, but higher security has its price because it must beultimately paid for by policyholders and cedants or shareholders,Schweizerische Ruckversicherungs-Ges (Swiss Re) concludes in its latestSigma study*.  "Just as investors are prepared to accept a lower returnon a bond issue with a high rating, so policyholders and cedants mustbe prepared to pay higher premiums to a company with high security,"the study said.Since 1978, 648 non-life insurers worldwide have become insolvent.  Atthe end of the 1970s, the number of insolvencies annually averagedabout 10, but by the 1990s had increased to about 80.  Although in 1994there was a decline to just above 40, it was too early to speak of areversal of the trend, Swiss Re considered.  Two-thirds (66%) of theinsolvencies between 1978 and 1994 involved US companies, while inEurope, UK insurers were most bankruptcy-prone, with 7% of the worldtotal.  Europe excluding the UK accounted for 4% (and at the same timefor 26% of global premium income).  Elsewhere, Bermuda represented 8%of bankruptcies.According to Swiss Re, the causes of insurance insolvencies arecomplex.  In general, bankruptcy is greater in deregulated markets, asthese are exposed to greater fluctuations in premium rates, and theprofitability of the market as a whole tends to be both lower and morevolatile.  The US and UK markets were also adversely affected by highburdens of loss from liability claims and natural disasters.  Prolongedperiods of falling interest rates also probably favour insolvencies, itsaid.  Swiss Re expects that, especially in Europe, deregulation ofinsurance markets and the replacement of material control by financialsupervision will increase competition and insurance market volatility,exacerbating the risk of insolvency.The study also analysed various methods for assessing solvency.  "Takenin isolation, the solvency ratio means little.  The reserves ratio atleast must also be taken into account," Swiss Re said, adding thatgenerally, the use of premium volumes as a measure of exposure to riskswas "problematic".  There were distortions as a result of fluctuatingpremium rates and different portfolio composition, and investment riskswere ignored.  In deregulated markets, insurance supervisionessentially consists of financial supervision, based in the EU onrelatively simple solvency ratios.  In the US, new risk-based capitalapproaches were already being used, under which both underwriting andinvestment risks assumed are quantified and used to determine thenecessary capital.  The study discusses several alternatives, includingsimulation models and Swiss Re's own method of measuring its necessaryrisk-adjusted capital.This it describes as follows.  "The capital requirement is calculatedin accordance with the business risk, that is to say on the basis ofthe probability distribution of the annual operating results.  Thisdistribution is made up of the results distributions of the variouslines of business and of investments.  The individual distributions aredetermined in two stages: firstly, from empirical data from the past, aprobability function of the results is formed which is adjusted bydisregarding exceptional major events.  Secondly, using so-called`threat scenarios' (for the various lines of business and investments),exceptional loss events of the kind which, on the basis of Swiss Re'sportfolio, are to be expected statistically every 10, 20, 50 and 100years are simulated.  The adjusted distributions and the distributionsof the exceptional events are combined to form the resultsdistributions.  From these, the probability distribution of theoperating result is derived, taking account of the most importantcorrelations.  This means that the diversification effects of SwissRe's portfolio are included.  It is most unlikely that extremelyunfavourable events will occur in all regions and lines of business atthe same time, which means that an unfavourable result in one area canbe cushioned by a favourable result in another.The capital required is thus determined by the extent to which theExecutive Board is prepared to take risks.  The Executive Boardstipulates the probability with which, and the period over which, thecompany's financial strength is not to be adversely affected.The risk-adjusted capital determined in this way is then allocated tothe individual lines of business and profit centres on the basis of thevolatility of the results.  This allocation enables the results of thelines of business and profit centres to be measured adequately."Insurers' claims-paying ability is assessed not only by regulators butalso by private rating agencies, of which the best-known are Standard &Poor's, Moody's and AM Best.  Comparing individual agencies' ratingswas not without its problems either, Swiss Re said.  Definitions ofrating categories differed, as did rating procedures, but there was aclearly identifiable tendency for an ever smaller proportion ofinsurers to receive a top rating.  "Best's clearly rates more companiesas `excellent' than do Moody's and Standard & Poor's," Swiss Re said."Moody's is the most cautious in assigning the highest rating," itadded, but of the companies examined, only Standard & Poor's rated someas `vulnerable'.The accuracy of ratings was analysed with AM Best's data, looking atthe rating three years prior to a company's collapse.  Correspondingdata from the other rating agencies were not available.  For most ofthe companies becoming insolvent, the rating had been withdrawn or nonehad been assigned.  Three years before bankruptcy, 45 out of 247insurers had an A rating, and one year before only six.Development of insolvencies and the importance of security in theinsurance industry, Swiss Re sigma 7/1995, Swiss Re, Economic Research,POB, CH-8022 Zurich, Switzerland. Fax +41 1 285 2999.Back to Headline List CopyrightWORLD INSURANCE REPORT via NewsNetJanuary 12, 1996ROI IMPROVEDAlthough the US property/casualty insurance industry will show a rateof return on capital for 1995 of 9.2%, more than 60% higher than the5.6% achieved in 1994, the industry's profit rate remains below that ofmost other sectors according to a report published jointly by theInsurance Information Institute (I.I.I.) and Standard & Poor's (S&P).The Fortune 500 is expected to show a 13% rate of return for the year.Nevertheless, the rate of return for insurance in 1995 is slightlyabove its long-term rate of 9%.The increase was attributed to lower than expected catastrophe losses,and higher investment income and interest rates.  Catastrophes for 1995are expected to cost about US$8bn, down from $17bn in 1994, althoughHurricane Opal and some lesser storms made 1995 the third worst year onrecord for catastrophe losses, after 1994 and the record $23bn of 1992. Investment income increased by 10.4% in 1995 over 1994.  In 1994, theincrease was an "anaemic" 3.4%, after declines of 1.5% and 3.2% in 1992and 1993.  Interest rates rose in 1994 and remained relatively high inearly 1995, so insurers could invest new funds in higher-yieldingassets.  Record stockmarket highs also generated  increases in capitalgains, while the fall in interest rates in Q3-Q4 1995 added to therealised gains of insurers which sold bonds.  Realised capital gainsincreased to $5bn last year, from $1.7bn in 1994.Overall profitability for 1996 is expected to show further significantgrowth, mainly due to investment income as premium growth is slowed bysevere price competition.  Alan Levin of S&P predicted a combined ratioof 107.9% for 1996, and a continued fall in the quality of earnings asunderwriting losses increase through 1997.  "As a result, we expect tosee even more action in controlling expenses, possibly through moremergers as insurers attack their cost base in order to preserve profitmargins.  With underwriting expenses accounting for approximately 26%of net premium volume, internal expense control becomes the onlyalternative open to insurers as a means for maintaining adequateprofitability," Mr Levin said.A similar conclusion was reached by a study* by the Insurance ServicesOffice Inc (ISO), which measured risk as the variability in return onyear-end net worth for the 20 largest insurers and the 20 largestcompanies in 30 non-property/casualty insurance industry groups,including life/health insurers.  It found that from 1979 to 1993 themedian rate of return for the 20 largest p/c insurers was 9.6%, 1.6points below the average of the corresponding medians for the 20largest companies in each of the non-insurance groups.  It also foundthat insurance was riskier than most non-insurance industries on eachof three measures of variability used to assess risk, total variabilityin rate of return, a variability adjusted for industry cycles and anISO composite index averaging the first two.The number of industry groups more profitable and less risky thaninsurance was about three times the number which were the reverse.Similar results were found when ISO examined all companies in industrygroups, not just the 20 largest.  However, about a quarter ofindividual insurers analysed were superior to the typical company inthe non-insurance industry groups.  The property/casualty industry's10.1% average rate of return during the two insurance cycles for 1978to 1994 also was lower than the corresponding rates of return for fiveout of six key composite indices, including the Standard & Poor's 500and the Standard & Poor's Financials.The study found that stockholder-owned insurers earned higher returns,but faced greater risk than policyholder-owned mutuals.  Commercial-lines insurers have also been more profitable, but faced more risk thanpersonal-lines insurers, and agency companies have been more profitablebut also more risky than direct writers.  The major short-tail propertylines have been more profitable, but also more risky than the majorlong-tail lines, catastrophes increasing the volatility in property andyear-to-year changes in reserve adequacy smoothing results forliability.*Risks and Returns: Property/Casualty Insurance Compared with otherIndustries, ISO.Back to Headline List CopyrightWORLD INSURANCE REPORT via NewsNetJanuary 12, 1996STATE REINSURER, NEW COMPANIESYang Wenyou, director of the Administration Department for Foreign FundFinancial Organs of the People's Bank of China, said on 30 Decemberthat a State Reinsurance Company would be established to break themonopoly of the People's Insurance Co of China (PICC), Beijing, whichhe said created unfair competition between the PICC and its potentialcompetitors which was unfavourable for the healthy development of theinsurance market (WIR527/7). The year 1995 hadprovided a "breathing space for the insurance industry, which has beenhaving to cope with particularly heavy claims burdens from naturalcatastrophes for nearly ten years," it added.The company also drew attention to an important and mainly positive,factor: the long-lasting El Niuo effect, a natural cyclical warming ofthe tropical Pacific, came to an end in 1995.  El Niuo had resulted inextreme drought in Australia and heavy rainfall on the US Pacificcoast, but had also contributed to a reduction of hurricane activity inthe Caribbean.According to Munich Re, the number of events it categorises as naturalcatastrophes rose from 580 in 1994 to about 600 in 1995 which claimed atotal of 18,000 lives, up from 10,150.  In terms of economic losses,1995 was a record year, the total of US$180bn dwarfing the $65bn of1994, the previous worst year.  In 1995, however, insured lossesreached only $14bn, compared to $28bn in 1992 and $17bn in 1994.  Thisresulted from the fact that insurance density in the regions most badlyaffected in 1995 was comparatively low.This applied in particular to what was, in economic terms, the mostexpensive natural catastrophe to date, the Great Hanshin Earthquakewhich struck Kobe on 17 January and caused overall losses of about$100bn.  Although of only medium intensity, it reduced parts of theindustrial and port city to rubble and ashes.  More than 6,000 peoplewere killed and 300,000 left homeless. One way, it suggested, is for insurers tothrow their weight behind the introduction of mandatory building codesas a means of minimising damage from natural hazards.  Only threeCaribbean countries, two of them British colonies (the Bahamas,Anguilla and Monserrat) have such codes.The Barbados-based CCEO is in the final phase of drawing up acomprehensive Caribbean Uniform Building Code (CUBIC), which it wouldlike adopted by all the other 12 members of CARICOM, the Caribbean freetrade area.  The code will outline the design and constructionparameters for all new buildings.  The organisation would like theinsurance industry to be more active in pressing governments to enforcethe Code, a spokesman said, and with the Caribbean just havingexperienced its worst hurricane season for 62 years and insurers stillcounting the costs, it feels the industry, with the prodding ofreinsurers, may now be ready to take notice.Tony Gibbs, a senior Caribbean engineer who has been one of the mostactive in promoting CUBIC, said Caribbean insurers would be doingthemselves a favour by supporting mandatory building standards, if onlybecause "it will remove an easy excuse for the high catastropheinsurance premiums the region must bear at the present time".One reason why most Caribbean governments have not moved to enforce theCode is a desire to avoid raising building costs. While previouslegislation referred only to injuries at work and employer's liability,the new law also covers loss prevention.  The main features of the newlegislation are- insurance is made compulsory, but employers may also choose to self-insure if they can demonstrate sufficient financial strength to paymonetary benefits and the ability to deliver required medical and otherservices (medical care and medication; prostheses and orthopaedics;rehabilitation; occupational retraining and funeral services).  Theability of employers to provide benefits in kind if uninsured iscurrently unsupervised- employers are relieved of civil liability unless there is proof of awrongful, intentional act.  Under existing legislation, workers canchoose between accepting the scheduled compensation or going to court,leading over the years to tens of thousands of cases with enormouslosses for insurers and reinsurers- a new type of specialised workers' compensation insurer, known asARTs, is to be created.  These must have a minimum paid-in capital ofPesos3m.  General insurers who write workers' comp may continue doingso if they provide the new services provided by the act.  ARTs andinsurers will choose which industrial sectors they will cover, butcannot turn down any request for cover from employers in those sectors- disability income to be based on a monthly income instead of lump sumpayments, expected current value of the periodic benefit being limitedto Pesos55,000 (US$55,000) during the first three years of the newsystem and Pesos110,000 thereafter- only enumerated occupational diseases and disabilities will becovered and the list of diseases regulated- loss prevention and worker rehabilitation and retraining, andcollective labour negotiations to improve prevention and benefits, areall encouraged- benefits will be financed with monthly contributions paid byemployers.  Guarantee and reserve funds will be created andadministered by a new Workers' Compensation Superintendency and theInsurance Superintendency, respectively.Back to Headline List CopyrightWORLD INSURANCE REPORT via NewsNetJanuary 12, 1996LANDMARK MEDMAL RULINGThe Supreme Court of India has held that patients who receiveincompetent service either from doctors or hospitals can claim damagesunder the Consumer Protection Act 1986 (CPA), leading doctors to seekcover against potential liabilities.  The National Consumer Commission(NCC), constituted under the CPA, ruled in April 1992 that theprovision of paid medical assistance by hospitals and medicalprofessionals fell within the scope of the term "service" as defined insection 2(1)(0) of the CPA.  In the event of any deficiency in theperformance of such services, the aggrieved party may file a complaintto the Consumer Forum under the CPA.  The NCC decision was challengedby the Medical Council of India.The Supreme Court (Justices Kuldip Singh, SC Agarwal and BL Hansaria)upheld the NCC ruling, excepting only services rendered by a doctorpractising free of charge to every patient under a contract of personalservice, by way of consultation, diagnosis or treatment.The judges commented that a contract of personal service must bedistinguished from a contract of professional service.  They alsoobserved that they were unable to support the view that merely becausemedical practitioners belong to the medical profession, they areoutside the purview of the provisions of the Act and the servicesrendered by them are not covered by it.  The normal tests of negligenceshould apply.  The court further observed that while immunity fromdamages could be granted on grounds of public interest, the trend wasfor restricting of such immunity.The verdict brings to an end years of controversy generated bydiffering decisions by various High Courts.  Among the possible reliefswhich could be granted plaintiffs are return of charges paid,compensation for loss or injury suffered due to negligence andremedying of the defective or deficient service.  The Supreme Courtdecision evoked a mixed reaction.  The Honorary General Secretary ofthe India Medical Association, Dr JC Sobti, pointed out that henceforthprivate doctors would increasingly seek insurance cover on the lines ofthe US system.A random survey of private nursing homes in Delhi revealed that themajority of doctors had already bought a professional indemnity policyor planned to do so, and many of those already covered planned toincrease the sum insured.  At one home, all 35 medical consultants hadbeen instructed by the hospital director to take out cover for Rs1m(US$28,230) each, while the director had already sought cover forhimself and paramedical staff at a cost of about Rs40,000 in annualpremium.Back to Headline List CopyrightWORLD INSURANCE REPORT via NewsNetJanuary 12, 1996PROPERTY AND BUSINESS INTERRUPTION1.2.94-1.1.95, fire, statisticsUK:  London, Fire Protection Association (FPA), ests total loss from156 #250,000+ (US$400,000) fires at #179.7m (US$279m).1.3.94-28.2.95, fire, statisticsUK:  London, Fire Protection Association (FPA), ests total loss from152 #250,000+ (US$400,000) fires at #176.5m (US$274.1m).1.1-28.2.95, fire, statisticsUK:  London, Fire Protection Association (FPA) ests total loss from 12#250,000+ (US$400,000) fires at #8.6m (US$13.4m). [DOCUMENT] Harassment of Journalists Intensifies Africa News Service January 15, 1996 (19960115)    New York - Text of several recent news alerts by the New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ).    On 12 January 1996, Stanton Peabody, acting managing director of the "Daily Observer", was released after Press Union of Liberia attorneys, through the Justice & Peace Commission, filed a bill of habeus corpus on his behalf. Peabody was released on bail of $20,000 Liberian (US$ 400).    Peabody will return to court on 16 January, as will editor-in- chief of the "Daily Observer" James Seitua. However, the two journalists will be tried separately on charges of "criminal malevolence."    Immediately after the court ordered Peabody's release, Director of National Police Joseph Tate ordered seven police officers to re-arrest him in the courthouse. However, the presiding judge announced that any re-arrest would place Tate in contempt of court. Peabody plans to remain at home until the upcoming court date.   On 11 January 1996, representatives of the Press Union of Liberia and the management of the "Daily Observer" obtained a bill of release for James Seitua, editor-in-chief of the "Daily Observer". Bail in the amount of $25,000 Liberian dollars ($350 US) was paid. Under the conditions of his release, Seitua cannot travel outside of Monrovia, and must report daily to the police until the matter is resolved.   The charge against Seitua, as stated in his bill of release, is "criminal malevolence." No charges have been filed against him in a court of law. On 29 December 1995, the "Daily Observer" published an article that disputed the claim made by United Revolutionary Front of Sierra Leone spokesperson Eddie Hebron that he was interviewed in the Ivory Coast by the British Broadcasting Corporation and Voice of America. The article claimed that Hebron was in Monrovia, the Liberian capital, during the interviews. James Seitua was subsequently arrested on 9 January and detained; he has since been released on bail. Stanton Peabody, in an attempt to intervene on Seitua's behalf, was also arrested on 10 January. He remains in detention.   On 8 January 1996, D. Sompon Weah II, reporter for "The News", and "The News" photographer Pewee S. Flomoku were attacked in Po River (northwestern Liberia), where they were covering skirmishes between West Africa peacekeeping forces (ECOMOG) and warring factions of the United Liberation Movement (ULIMO-J).   The attack occurred shortly after their arrival, as they were recording the state of security in the region. At the directive of the executive director of the Liberia Refugees Repatriation & Resettlement Commission, Mrs. Weade Kobbah Wreh, they were beaten by her personal bodyguards and some ECOMOG soldiers. Flomoku's camera was destroyed.    For further information, contact Kakuna Kerina, program coordinator for Africa at (212) 465-1004 x 103; fax: (212) 465-9568; e-mail: kkerina@cpj.org-0-Back to Headline List CopyrightAFRICA NEWS ON-LINE via NewsNetJanuary 29, 1996Nigeria[DOCUMENT] Press Group Condemns Attacks on Press Africa News ServiceJanuary 16, 1996 (19960116)   New York - Statement by the New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists.  The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ), a nonpartisan advocate of press freedom, condemns the December 23 arrest of Nosa Igiebor, editor in chief of best-selling Lagos-based "Tell" magazine, and the recent escalation of attacks against Nigeria's independent press.    Igiebor, the recipient of CPJ's International Press Freedom Award in 1993, was arrested by six members of the State Security Service (SSS) at his home in Lagos. SSS agents also confiscated 20,000 copies of "Tell" magazine's Christmas Day edition with the cover story "Abacha is Adamant: Terrorizes the Opposition." On December 27, SSS agents made a failed attempt to search his office for the company's tax records and staff pay records.   Authorities continue to hold Igiebor in solitary confinement without charge, and are demanding that he reveal his sources for articles published in Tell criticizing the military government. During interrogations at Lagos State Command of the SSS facility in Shangisha, Igiebor repeatedly stated that he receives financial support from neither outsiders nor Nigerian citizens, and that any information he receives arrives by mail.    CPJ also denounces the following attacks against the independent press during the last two weeks of 1995:   * On December 31, the office of the magazine division of the Independent Communications Network Limited, publishers of "The News," "Tempo," and "Tempofootball," was torched by arsonists using a petrol bomb. According to Dapo Olorunyomi, editor -in-chief of "The News," the fire destroyed property (including a new line of Gateway 2000 Pentium computers) worth millions of naira. The arsonists managed to escape.   The office, located on the first floor of Tejumola House in Ikeja, Lagos, houses the newsroom and production center of the three magazines. It was the only floor of the four-story building that was torched. Management expects publication of The News and Tempo to be suspended for approximately two weeks.    On December 19, photojournalists Peter Obe, Bayo Ewuoso, Abiodun Ajala and Segun Olakitan were assaulted and detained by police during the National Democratic Coalition (NADECO) rally in Lagos. Their offense was photographing the confrontation between NADECO supporters and the over five hundred policemen who shot tear gas into the crowd to disperse the protesters.    Ewuoso, a senior photojournalist with "AM News" was severely beaten by over ten policemen who later transported him to the Surulere Police Station for interrogation. Ajala of "This Day" newspaper, Olakitan of "Tell" magazine, and veteran photojournalist Obe were also beaten and seriously injured by police. Ajala and Olakitan were rushed to a nearby hospital for treatment.   On December 16, ten security operatives lay siege to the "AM News" office, demanding to know the whereabouts of editor-in-chief Bayo Onanuga. They were seeking Onanuga to place him under arrest. Onanuga remains in hiding. The security operatives reportedly did the same at the offices of "Tell" magazine.    On December 16, all 55,000 copies of "Tell" were seized at the printing house. The seizure followed the magazine's publication of an article titled "The Release of [Chief Moshood] Abiola: The World Waits On [General Sani] Abacha."    On December 15, arsonists torched the circulation department of "The Guardian" newspaper. Damage was minimal because the fire was quickly brought under control.   On December 15, Adedisi Dejo, Emmanuel Piper, Yeni Oldwolabi and Iyi Isaac, reporters and contributors to the paper, were held for questioning by Lagos police.   Finally, CPJ intensified its call for the release of the four journalists (Christine Anyanwu, George Mbah, Ben Charles Obi and Kunle Ajibade) who were convicted to fifteen years in jail for their alleged participation in an alleged coup plot against the military regime.   For further information, contact Kakuna Kerina, program coordinator for Africa at (212) 465-1004 x 103; fax: (212) 465-9568; e-mail: kkerina@cpj.org -0- Back to Headline List CopyrightAFRICA NEWS ON-LINE via NewsNetJanuary 29, 1996United States and Africa[DOCUMENT] Investment Myths About Africa Dispelled in TV ProgramU.S. Africa Chamber of CommerceJanuary 15, 1996 (19960115)   New York - The U.S.-Africa Chamber of Commerce dispels investment myths about Africa with its first televised program, "Africa: An Emerging Market for the 90s." The 30-minute special, hosted by CNBC Anchor Karen Gibbs, travels to businesses in Egypt, Ghana and South Africa.   The program features a distinguished panel of experts on investing in Africa including, international investor Jom Rogers; His Excellency Ekwow Spio-Garbrah, Ambassador from Ghana; Donald Norland, former Ambassador of Chad and Botswana; Susan Levine, Overseas Private Investment Corporation and Maceo Sloan, president and CEO of Sloan Financial Group, who served as moderator.   It also features guest appearances by President Nelson Mandela (South Africa), President Jerry Rawlings (Ghana) and celebrities Danny Glover, Louis Gossett, Jr., Bryant Gumbel, Nigel Hawthorne, Iman, John McLaughlin, Gary Player and Alfre Woodard.   The program will be seen nationwide on local stations in Atlanta, Chicago, Los Angeles, New York and Washington, DC. It will air throughout January, February and March. The producers anticipate pick-up by cable outlets such as CNBC and BET in February and March.   "For so long I have wanted to show the U.S. audience what Africa has to offer," says Elias Belayneh, president of the U.S.-Africa Chamber of Commerce. "Now, I have the opportunity to broaden U.S. investor interest in Africa. Watching this production will be unparalleled to any other African special seen on television."   "Africa gets in your soul, you either love it or hate it," adds participant Jim Rogers. "I love it; it's a great investment."   The show was produced by Noelle-Elaine Productions, a New York-based production company. The U.S.-Africa Chamber of Commerce is an independent, non-profit organization establishing ties between the U.S. and foreign businesses, trade organizations, universities, foundations and individuals to promote the efficiency and integrity of trade and investment in the U.S. and Africa.   For more information, call Lisa Donadio, Noelle-Elaine Media Consultants, 212 370-5485.-0-Back to Headline List CopyrightAFRICA NEWS ON-LINE via NewsNetJanuary 29, 1996UgandaUK Report Predicts Museveni Win In '96 PollsThe Monitor (Kampala)January 5, 1996 (19960105)by Gerald Owachi   Kampala - A report issued by the authoritative London-based Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) has predicted a Museveni victory in the forthcoming presidential elections.   "It will be very surprising if President Yoweri Museveni, is not returned to office next April as the elected president,: the just released 1995 4th quarter country report, says.   The report, however, doubts whether all sections of society will accept the legitimacy of his election.   At the same time it casts a shadow over the loyalty of the army towards any other person other than Museveni. "The army remains Mr. Museveni's trump card," it states, therefore disqualifying the possibilities of the army supporting any other democratically elected government.   It also suggests that the legislative elections in May 1996 will produce a better political balance in parliament, and thereby defuse some political tension.   According to the report, NRM is already confident of victories in Karamoja -- because NRM has allowed the K'jongs to keep their guns. Busoga--VP Kazibwe's home area, Bugisu, Kapchorwa and his traditional base the South-west.   The report further states that, "Mr Museveni is even trying to tempt former president, Idi Amin, back to Uganda in order to capitalise on his support in the North West.   The EIU report which briefly portrays the current political and economic state of Uganda, Rwanda and Burundi, cites the new constitution and the escalating military expenditure of the Uganda government as a possible source of disagreement between the donor community and the Government.   According to the report, "the USA clearly believes that a five-year wait before the issue of multi-partyism can again be tested is too long. It adds that European countries previously reluctant to show their resentment on the matter, have now formally joined the US in pressing for an early constitutional amendment.   "The government reduced the defence share of budget expenditure from 36% in 1990/91 to 13% in 1991/92, but then raised it again during the following two years and brought it up to 30% this year [1995}," the reports notes. The donor community is not at all happy with this trend regardless of the insecurity in the north and along the Sudan border.   The report says that the rift between president Moi of Kenya and Museveni which used to be portrayed as a largely personal matter, has developed into "a more substantial rift based on the different approaches to systems of government." It blames the failure to achieve regional cooperation on this cat and mouse relationship between these two leaders.   The strike by medical workers last September is cited in the report as a possible beginning of demands to be floated by the public sector workers. This is the main finding of the Kumbleben Commission which this week released a 200-page report about its inquiry into the smuggling of rhino horn and elephant tusks in South Africa. The commission was appointed by President Nelson Mandela in October 1994.   Justice ME Kumbleben also criticises Operation Lock, the controversial covert operation by former British special forces officers to combat poaching in Southern Africa in the late 1980s, and says the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) and the head of its South African branch must take some responsibility for the behaviour of this unit.   The Kumbleben report finds there was large-scale destruction of wildlife, including elephants and rhinos, in north-eastern Namibia and Angola as a result of the 1980s wars in those countries. Most of the ivory and rhino horn obtained by poachers during this period was illegally exported through South Africa by SADF military intelligence.   The Roos Commission, set up by the defence force in 1988 to probe press reports of military involvement in the illicit trade, claimed that only about 500 tusks captured by Unita from poachers were handled by the military from 1978 onwards.   Kumbleben describes this commission as a "charade" designed to exonerate the SADF.   The report lambasts a scheme hatched by conservationists in the late 1980s to use former British special forces officers to combat poaching in Southern Africa. It describes Operation Lock -- financed by Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands and set up by John Hanks (then the WWF's project manager at its headquarters in Geneva) -- as being "accountable to no one".   Kumbleben also suggests that more than 100 rhino horns provided to these officers by the Natal Parks Board and conservation authorities in Namibia for supposed sting operations were later misappropriated by members of Operation Lock.   Sections of the report contain extracts from a secret document (called Q in the report) which shows that the anti-poaching operation was infiltrated by members of South African military intelligence after it set up headquarters in South Africa. This was apparently designed to ensure Operation Lock could be "put to good use by the necessary South African information collecting departments".   The document claims that Colonel Ian Crooke, the commander of Operation Lock, had offered to help in "the monitoring of anti-South African bodies which are situated overseas".   Evidence presented to the commission suggests that document Q -- which appears to be an internal Operation Lock memo -- was drawn up by a South African military intelligence officer called Mike Richards, who had managed to infiltrate the operation.   Kumbleben questions claims by Hanks that the WWF, the world's biggest conservation NGO, was not aware of Operation Lock's activities.    It goes on to stress, however, that "those responsible for putting Lock in place did not have the ulterior motive of Lock functioning as some sort of espionage or intelligence collecting agency for the RSA. It was intended by them to be an anti-poaching or anti-smuggling operation and nothing more. It may have later been contaminated by other objectives and considerations referred to in document Q."   Hanks said his involvement in purchasing rhino horn to entrap smugglers was a sincere attempt to save Africa's dwindling black rhino stocks.   "It was nothing to do with Operation Lock, it was a totally different project. The WWF had done nothing wrong in this regard."   With the assistance of Prince Bernhard, Hanks raised R250 000 to purchase rhino horn to trap smugglers. Although the horn was never again accounted for, Hanks believes it was money well spent. "There was a group of people tested to do the undercover work. They never reported to the WWF."
